topic.name: Minor Prophets
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Minor Prophets in Bible & Theology

objectives.objective_text: Identify Amos as a shepherd.
Name justice as being fair to everyone.
Identify Habakkuk as a man who asked God questions.
Name the watchtower where he waited.
Identify Haggai as a prophet after the exile.
Name the Temple as what needed building.
Identify Hosea as the man who married Gomer.
Name God's love as a never-stopping love.
Identify the locusts as bugs that ate everything.
Name the 'Day of the Lord'.
Identify Jonah as the man swallowed by a big fish.
Name Nineveh as the city he didn't want to go to.
Identify Malachi as the last book of the Old Testament.
Name God as a Father.
Identify Micah as a prophet.
Name Bethlehem as the place a Ruler would come from.
Identify Nahum as a prophet against a bad city.
Name Nineveh again (after Jonah).
Identify Obadiah as a short book.
Name Edom as the enemy.
Identify Zechariah as a prophet with strange dreams.
Name the King coming on a donkey.
Identify Zephaniah as a prophet.
Name the 'Day of the Lord'.
Recall that God wants us to help the poor.
Observe that God sees how we treat others.
Recall 'The righteous shall live by faith'.
Observe that we can rejoice even when things are hard.
Recall that the people were building their own houses instead.
Observe that God wants to be first.
Recall that God forgives us when we run away.
Observe that God wants us to love Him back.
Recall that God promised to pour out His Spirit.
Observe that we should pray when bad things happen.
Recall that God loves people everywhere.
Observe that you can't run away from God.
Recall that the people were robbing God.
Observe that God promised to send Elijah before the end.
Recall that God wants us to be kind and humble.
Observe that God forgives sin.
Recall that God is slow to anger but strong.
Observe that God protects those who trust Him.
Recall that we shouldn't laugh when others get hurt.
Observe that God defends His people.
Recall that it is 'Not by might, nor by power, but by My Spirit'.
Observe that God cares about Jerusalem.
Recall that God sings over His people.
Observe that God will clean up the world.
Summarize Amos' warnings to the rich people.
Explain 'Let justice roll down like waters'.
Explain the 'Famine of the Word'.
Defend the importance of righteousness in society.
Produce an essay on the danger of religious hypocrisy.
Summarize Habakkuk's questions (Why do bad people win?).
Explain God's answer (He is using the Babylonians).
Explain the woe oracles against the Chaldeans.
Defend the sovereignty of God in using wicked nations.
Produce a reflection on finding joy in God alone.
Summarize the message: 'Consider your ways'.
Explain why the people stopped building (discouragement).
Explain the 'shaking of the heavens and earth'.
Defend the importance of the visible church/temple.
Produce an essay on overcoming spiritual apathy.
Summarize Hosea's marriage as a picture of God and Israel.
Explain what unfaithfulness means.
Explain the historical context of the Northern Kingdom.
Defend the relentless love of God ('Hesed').
Summarize the plague of locusts.
Explain the promise of the Holy Spirit.
Explain the call to national repentance.
Defend the necessity of repentance for restoration.
Summarize the story of Jonah's running and preaching.
Explain why Jonah was angry (he hated the Assyrians).
Explain the satire and irony in the book.
Defend the historicity of the book against 'parable' views.
Summarize the disputes between God and the people.
Explain the prophecy of the messenger (John the Baptist).
Explain the problem of divorce and intermarriage in Malachi.
Defend the immutability of God ('I the Lord do not change').
Summarize Micah 6:8 (Act justly, love mercy, walk humbly).
Explain the prophecy about Jesus' birth.
Explain the imagery of casting sins into the sea.
Defend the consistency of justice and mercy in God's character.
Produce a reflection on 'Who is a God like you?'
Summarize the judgment on Nineveh.
Explain that Nineveh went back to being bad after Jonah.
Explain why God's patience eventually ends.
Defend the justice of God in history.
Summarize the conflict between Jacob (Israel) and Esau (Edom).
Explain that pride brings people down.
Explain the lex talionis ('As you have done, it shall be done to you').
Defend God's justice in judging nations.
Summarize the prophecy of the King on a donkey (Palm Sunday).
Explain the vision of the lampstand and olive trees.
Explain the concept of the 'Branch'.
Defend the unity of the book (chapters 1-8 and 9-14).
Summarize the warning of judgment on the whole earth.
Explain the 'remnant' (the people who stay faithful).
Explain the image of God as a singing warrior.
Defend the necessity of judgment for true restoration.
Compare religious singing with real obedience.
Apply the lesson of caring for the needy.
Analyze the judgment on the nations in chapters 1-2.
Interpret the vision of the plumb line.
Connect social justice to true worship.
Compare complaining with trusting.
Apply the choice to rejoice in God no matter what (Habakkuk 3).
Analyze the dialogue between the prophet and God.
Interpret 'The just shall live by his faith'.
Connect Habakkuk to the coming Babylonian invasion.
Compare the small new temple with the glorious old one.
Apply the lesson of putting God's work first.
Analyze the connection between spiritual obedience and physical blessing.
Interpret the prophecy that the glory of the latter house will be greater.
Connect Haggai to Zerubbabel and Joshua the Priest.
Compare idolatry to cheating on a spouse.
Apply the call to return to the Lord.
Analyze the metaphor of spiritual adultery.
Interpret the names of Hosea's children (Not my people).
Connect Hosea's redemption of Gomer to Christ redeeming the church.
Compare a natural disaster with God's judgment.
Apply the call to rend hearts, not garments.
Analyze the concept of the 'Day of the Lord'.
Interpret the prophecy of the Spirit quoted in Acts 2.
Connect the locust plague to future judgment.
Compare God's mercy with Jonah's anger.
Apply the lesson that God cares for our enemies.
Analyze Jonah's prayer from the fish.
Interpret the sign of Jonah mentioned by Jesus.
Connect the book to Israel's failure to be a light to the nations.
Compare true worship with bored worship.
Apply the teaching on tithes and offerings.
Analyze the question-and-answer style of the book.
Interpret 'I have loved Jacob but hated Esau'.
Connect the 'Sun of Righteousness' to Jesus.
Compare false rulers with the Good Shepherd.
Apply the call to walk humbly with God.
Analyze the lawsuit motif in the book.
Interpret the prophecy of the mountain of the Lord.
Compare God as a stronghold with God as a flood.
Apply the truth that God judges evil.
Analyze the poetic description of the siege of Nineveh.
Interpret the character of God in Nahum 1.
Connect the fall of Nineveh to historical records.
Compare Edom's rocky fortress with God's power.
Apply the warning against pride.
Analyze the historical background of Edom.
Interpret 'The day of the Lord is near for all nations'.
Connect the judgment of Edom to the protection of Zion.
Compare the bad shepherds with the Good Shepherd.
Apply the promise of God's Spirit helping us.
Analyze the eight night visions.
Interpret the prophecy of the 30 pieces of silver.
Connect Zechariah to the rebuilding of the Temple.
Compare the bad day for enemies with the glad day for God's people.
Apply the verse 'He will quiet you with His love'.
Analyze the de-creation language in Zephaniah 1.
Interpret the call to seek righteousness and humility.
Connect Zephaniah to the reign of Josiah.
Evaluate the economic prosperity vs. moral decay of Israel.
Evaluate Paul's use of Habakkuk 2:4 in Romans and Galatians.
Evaluate the messianic significance of the signet ring.
Evaluate the shock value of the prophetic sign act.
Evaluate the use of Joel in Peter's Pentecost sermon.
Evaluate the ending of the book (the unanswered question).
Evaluate the prophecy of Elijah and its fulfillment in John the Baptist.
Evaluate the Messianic Shepherd-King prophecy.
Evaluate the moral necessity of divine wrath against cruelty.
Evaluate the sin of gloating over another's misfortune.
Evaluate the apocalyptic imagery and its relation to Revelation.
Evaluate the syncretism (mixing religions) condemned in the book.
Construct a theological response to the problem of evil based on Habakkuk.
Construct a timeline of the post-exilic period (Ezra/Haggai).
Synthesize Hosea's message with the New Testament bride imagery.
Construct a timeline of the fulfillment of Joel 2.
Synthesize the theme of judgment and blessing.
Construct a profile of the Assyrian cruelty to understand Jonah's reluctance.
Synthesize the missionary heart of God in the OT.
Construct a profile of the spiritual lethargy of the post-exilic community.
Synthesize the end of the OT and the 400 years of silence.
Connect Micah's message to his contemporary, Isaiah.
Construct a comparison of Jonah (mercy) and Nahum (judgment).
Synthesize the comfort Nahum brings to God's oppressed people.
Construct a history of the Edomite/Israelite conflict.
Synthesize the theme of the Kingdom belonging to the Lord.
Construct a list of Messianic prophecies in Zechariah.
Synthesize the theme of the piercing of the Messiah.
Construct a study on the 'Day of the Lord' theme.
Synthesize the joy of restoration in Zephaniah 3.
Construct a theology of social justice based on Amos.
Construct a theology of God's emotional engagement (jealousy/love).
Construct a theology of what God requires of man.
